stem: The labor and delivery nurse is assessing three clients. Based on the documentation in the EHR, match the Fetal Heart Rate (FHR) finding to its most likely physiological cause.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Client 1: 39-year-old G3P2 at 41 weeks. Oligohydramnios documented on yesterday's ultrasound.
Client 2: 24-year-old G1P0 at 38 weeks. Currently 9 cm dilated. Fetal head is visible at the introitus during contractions.
Client 3: 31-year-old G1P0 at 40 weeks. Client reports severe nausea and lightheadedness following the administration of an epidural block.

tabs.title: Clinical Trends
tabs.content:
ClientMaternal BPFHR FindingsTiming
Client 1118/72Abrupt drops in FHR from 140 to 90 bpmIndependent of contractions
Client 2128/80Gradual decrease from 140 to 125 bpmMirrors contraction peak
Client 388/52Gradual decrease from 150 to 110 bpmStarts after contraction peak

tabs.title: Ultrasound Result
tabs.content:
Client 1: Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) < 5 cm (Oligohydramnios).
Client 3: Placenta posterior, no evidence of abruption.

rows.text: Abrupt decelerations (V, U, or W-shaped) occurring at varying times
Gradual decelerations that begin and end with the contraction ('mirroring')
Gradual decelerations that begin after the contraction peak and return late

rationale.correct: Abrupt decelerations (r1) are Variable decelerations, caused by cord compression (often due to oligohydramnios, as seen in Client 1). Gradual decelerations that mirror the contraction (r2) are Early decelerations, caused by head compression (Client 2 is 9 cm dilated/crowning). Gradual decelerations that start late (r3) are Late decelerations, caused by uteroplacental insufficiency (often due to maternal hypotension, seen in Client 3).
clinicalPearls: Early decelerations require no intervention; just continue monitoring.
Variable decelerations often require maternal position change (side-lying or knee-chest).
Late decelerations require the 'LION' protocol: Left-side, IV bolus, Oxygen, Notify provider.

questionTrap.trap: Believing all early decelerations require fetal scalp stimulation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Early decelerations are normal during active labor/descent. Do not treat them as an emergency.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: V-Variable = C-Cord compression. E-Early = H-Head compression. A-Accels = O-Okay. L-Late = P-Placental insufficiency.
